title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for teacher stabilization to prevent layoffs and create jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves funds for assistance to outlying areas, the Secretary of the Interior, and administration and oversight. The award amount is determined by the Secretary. The Secretary determines grant amounts for each State based on population ratios. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds. The Secretary reallocates grant funds to States based on population ratios if a State does not receive a grant. If needed, the Secretary will reallocate a State's grant allocation to other States using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State chief executives must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of this Act's enactment to request a grant. The application must include an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at a certain level for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The State chief executive must submit a letter within 30 days of the Act's enactment if they do not wish to receive a grant. The Secretary may waive the assurance requirement under certain circumstances such as natural disasters or a significant decline in the State's financial resources. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. State grants under this title require each State to reserve a portion of the grant funds for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies to support early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education. The State allocates grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and previous funding received under part A of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State must distribute grant funds to local educational agencies within 100 days of receiving the grant. The State is prohibited from using the funds to establish or supplement a rainy-day fund, supplant State funds, or reduce debt obligations. Local educational agencies receiving subgrants must use funds for employee expenses related to educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106 of the document outlines that State-funded early learning programs must use funds for educator compensation and expenses to retain, recall, or hire new early childhood educators. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107 requires States to report on fund usage and job support annually. SEC. 108 provides definitions. SEC. 108 defines key terms such as "local educational agency", "outlying area", and "State educational agency". It also clarifies that "State" refers to the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. Additionally, it defines a "State-funded early learning program" as a program receiving State funding for educational services to children up to kindergarten entry. SEC. 109 authorizes $30 billion for the grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION

The purpose is to provide funds to States and localities to prevent layoffs of, and support the creation of additional jobs for, law enforcement officers and firefighters. The firefighter grant program is also included. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. An additional $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for this purpose, with a reservation of up to $2 million by the Secretary. Homeland Security reserves up to $2 million annually for administrative costs related to firefighter grants. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. An additional $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
